hooks = knitr::knit_hooks$get()
hook_foldable = function(type) {
  force(type)
  function(x, options) {
    res = hooks[[type]](x, options)
    
    if (isFALSE(options[[paste0("fold.", type)]])) return(res)
    
    paste0(
      "<details open><summary>", gsub("^p", "P", gsub("^o", "O", type)), "</summary>\n\n",
      res,
      "\n\n</details>"
    )
  }
}

knitr::knit_hooks$set(
  output = hook_foldable("output"),
  plot = hook_foldable("plot")
)

Finally, you can type math using "Latex".  You will not *have* to write many equations, but it might make your life a bit easier if you know how to write simple things like $\beta$, $\beta_{0}$, $\widehat{\beta}$, $\times$, $\implies$, $\sum$, $\epsilon$, $\alpha$, $x^{2}$, $\text{Words}_{i}\times \beta$.  Most latex you'll end up writing will almost certainly be using things like this.  Use two dollar signs to place equations on their own lines like:

$$Y = \alpha + \beta X + \epsilon$$

You can use `code font` like this, and you can execute R code "inline" like this: `r "hello world!"` or `r 2 + 2`.
